context: [1] Extraction of Ricin-binding Glycoproteins, SDS-PAGE, and Western Blottingâ€”Bloodstream form T. brucei (strain 427, variant 117), were isolated from infected rats and purified over DEAE-cellulose .  [2] Parasites were subjected to hypotonic lysis to release cytosolic components as well as the majority of the VSG coat as soluble form VSG .  [3] The cell ghost pellets (1011 cell equivalents) were solubilized in 50 ml of 8 m urea, 3% SDS, 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8.  [4] The SDS/urea extract was diluted 50 times in buffer A (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 400 mm NaCl, and 0.8% Triton X-100, 0.1 mm 1-chloro-3-tosylamido-7-amino-2-heptanone, 1 Î¼g/ml leupeptin, and 0.1% sodium azide) to allow affinity chromatography on ricin-agarose (Vector Laboratories).  [5] Ricin-coupled agarose (4-ml packed volume) was added to the suspension and rotated gently overnight at 4 Â°C.  [6] Ricin-agarose was recovered by gentle centrifugation and packed into a 15 Ã— 1-cm column.  [7] The column was washed with 5 volumes of buffer A, and bound material was eluted with 30 mg/ml lactose and 30 mg/ml Gal in 4-fold diluted buffer A. Aliquots of the eluted fractions were separated on NuPAGE bis-Tris 4â€“12% gradient gels (Invitrogen).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea and heptanone are mentioned in a biochemical procedure involving the extraction and purification of glycoproteins from T. brucei. Urea is used in the solubilization process of cell components, while heptanone is included as a reagent in the buffer for affinity chromatography. However, there is no direct interaction or significant relationship between urea and heptanone beyond their roles in the experimental setup.
